creditline: The Mary Ruth Weisel Endowment for Africa, Oceania, and the Americas
department: Art of Africa and the Americas
description: standing stylized figure with pointed beard; triangular-shaped ears; pair of very tall horns with spirals at top; face has deeply-incised geometric patterns--without facial features; deeply carved oval element with horizontal band on chest; figure wears short skirt-like garment; figure stands on round platform with four curving legs and one vertical central leg; some possible scattered bits of red and white pigments
text: Ikenga, or “place of strength,” is the Nigerian Igbo name for this type of figure. A personal altar, it is a source of power, aggression, and achievement for the man who owns it. In Igbo society individual success and upward mobility are highly desirable. Before any major undertaking, like enrolling at a university, making an economic deal, or participating in an election, the owner of an ikenga would address it with prayers and offerings of food and kola nuts. Here, the stylized figure stands on a stool to make it taller and give it extra authority. Its head is adorned with long horns, a reference to a ram’s force and stubbornness.
title: Ikenga Figure
